Lack of evidence: The expert's verdict mentions that the Facebook post reporting the claim provided no evidence to support the assertion that George Soros is grooming Abdul El-Sayed to be president. This lack of evidence undermines the authenticity of the claim.
Source of inspiration: The expert's verdict states that the Facebook post appears to have been inspired by an April 2017 story in the far-right tabloid WND.com. This aspect highlights the potential bias and questionable credibility of the source that influenced the claim.
Troubling comments: The expert's verdict mentions that the Facebook post prompted troubling comments. This aspect suggests that the claim may have incited divisive or inflammatory reactions, further questioning its authenticity.
Conspiracy theory association: The expert's verdict highlights that the claim connects to the anti-Semitic conspiracy theory known as the "New World Order." This aspect indicates that the claim aligns with a baseless and widely discredited conspiracy theory, casting doubt on its authenticity.
